content-containers.name: about
content-containers.title: Thoreau's Spyglass
content-containers.description: Thoreau preferred to observe nature with the naked eye, not through a lens. It was after much internal debate that he decided to spend $8 .00 < br > --a rare splurge-- < br > on this spyglass in the spring of 1854. He was delighted with his enhanced ability to study bird behaviors and other natural phenomena.

content-containers.name: curious
content-containers.text: Thoreau did have a curious mind and one that wanted to understand if you tugged at one thread of the universe, right, what else would come up with it…
content-containers.author: Laura Walls, Historian

content-containers.name: his-experiments
content-containers.text: His experiments, his observations, his writings and even his later more scientific essays were all devoted to what we would call ecological science, the study of relationships, including most innovatively, the study of forest succession, right in the forests around his home in Concord.
content-containers.author: Laura Walls, Historian

content-containers.name: some-scientific
content-containers.text: Some scientific work that is still looked at as fundamental to ecological studies today.
content-containers.author: Laura Walls, Historian

content-containers.name: would-it-not
content-containers.text: “Would it not be well to carry a spy glass in order to watch these shy birds-- such as ducks and hawks?”
content-containers.author: Henry David Thoreau
